title: BTS ARMY can’t save the band from mandatory army service
text:
Band member Jin’s deadline to serve is fast approaching

When you hear BTS and ARMY in the same sentence, you probably assume we’re talking about BTS’s iconic fanbase.

Except this time, we’re talking about a real army.

Last week, the Hollywood Reporter received word from South Korea’s Ministry of Defence that BTS members will not be exempt from South Korea’s mandatory military service.

Since 1957, men in South Korea between the ages of 18 and 28 have had to complete roughly two years of mandatory military service.

Jin is the oldest member of BTS and will likely be the first to have to do his service. (Frazer Harrison/Getty Images)

Jin, who is one of seven musicians in the K-pop supergroup, turns 27 in December.

Many are wondering what will happen to the band as he and other members approach their deadline for serving.

When asked about it earlier this year on CBS Sunday Morning, Jin was clear about the band’s intentions to serve.

“As a Korean, it’s natural, and someday, when duty calls, we’ll be ready to respond and do our best.”

Despite BTS’s massive success and worldwide impact, they still won’t be exempt.

If not BTS, who gets a pass?

Turns out, certain people in Korea can be excused from military service.

South Korean Olympic swimmer Park Tae-hwan is just one of many athletes to be exempt from mandatory military service. (Adam Pretty/Getty Images)

Public figures like Olympic athletes and even artists, including classical musicians, have been permitted to skip their service in the past.

But K-pop bands are not yet eligible to be given a pass, based on current conscription rules.

South Korea’s Ministry of Defence has started conversations about changing the rules, but until then, the meteoric rise of BTS may come to a standstill.

Are South Koreans alone?

Mandatory military service exists in 26 different countries, including Norway and Brazil.

In South Korea, women aren’t required to serve but may volunteer if they wish.

In countries like Israel, both men and women are required to serve. (Amir Cohen/Reuters)

If not exempt, let the brotherhood stay together

Since they are not exempt, many fans on Twitter are sharing a petition to allow BTS to complete their service together.

The thinking is to get it all done in two years, rather than continuing with members leaving at different times.

The petition already has more than 20,000 signatures, but we’ll have to wait and see if the BTS ARMY can yet again pull through for their supergroup.

CBC Kids News reached out to BTS for comment, but has not heard back.
description: K-pop superband BTS will not be exempt from South Korea’s mandatory military service.
